We dined here tonight as a party of four and while I dropped ~$300 it was a three course meal.  Service by Dar-- was outstanding through out the night.  The kitchen helped her by being timely with every course. 

Appetizers were Hummus and Calamari, both were outstanding, but I believe the Calamari may have been the best Calamari appetizer I've every had.

Our mains were Gnocchi, Chicken Shashlik, Lamb Adana and I had the special of the night- Lamb Chops.  All of the dishes were quite nice but the two Lamb dishes were outstanding.

Deserts were Rice Pudding, Baklava, Sorbet and Chocolate Souffle and all four were quickly consumed. 

We'll eat here next time we are back in NYC.

review_text:
It’s been ages since I’ve been to Pera. I walk past it twice a day several time a week and think fondly of the lovely lunches and dinners I’ve had there over the years.  Last evening’s dinner falls right into place in that catalog of fond memories.

We lingered over our aperitifs, looking at the menu and catching up. Our waiter was handsome and pleasant. The restaurant was  not crowded or noisy. It gets no better than that.  For her first course, my friend ordered the Mediterranean Salad; cucumbers, cherry tomatoes, and Kalamata olives, beautifully presented, with a large block of creamy sheeps’ milk feta cheese on top.  I ordered the watermelon feta salad, here served with a basil dressing.  Squares of watermelon and feta are arranged in a geometric shape, the bright green dressing complementing the red and white of the salad. It was as pleasing to the eye as it was to the palate.

For her main course, my friend  chose the lamb chops; 5 little lamb chops, perfectly cooked, and served with roasted fingerling potatoes and bright red piquillo  peppers. She shared a lamb chop with me; it was divine.  And I shared my Signature Lamb Adana with her, a wonderful combination of ground lamb and spices.  The sides of bulgur pilaf and pickled vegetables were nice, but the tasty lamb was my main focus and I finished it.  We lingered for nearly two hours; another lovely dinner at Pera to contemplate the next time I walk past.

Lunch does big business in this attractive dining room, layered in a chocolate-brown color scheme and packed with corporate types as well as visitors looking for a sleek place to sojourn mid-day. Acoustics can be loud, but with food so fine, you’ll want to stay awhile.
Dinner is more low-key but the menu always brims with simple, good quality and slightly renovated plates like warm hummus with pastirma; lentil and bulgur tartare; or watermelon chunks tossed with salty feta, tomatoes and olive oil. A forkful of their model and deliciously tender chicken adana with a side of addictively crispy fries has wide appeal and makes for a fitting feast—at all times.
